2: The Knesset rules of procedure Ensure that the parliamentary information is open and accessible to the public. http://knesset.gov.il/rules/eng/contents.htm  http://main.knesset.gov.il/Activity/Pages/RulesOfProcedure.aspx Paragraph 38 of the rules and procedure of the parliament states that – "The minutes, as well as the detailed results of the electronic voting, shall be published on the Knesset website.". http://knesset.gov.il/rules/eng/ChapterC5.pdf   Paragraph 74 -  of the rules and procedure of the parliament states that Bills that have been laid on the Knesset table, shall be published on the Knesset website. http://knesset.gov.il/rules/eng/ChapterG1.pdf   Paragraph 118 of the rules and procedure of the parliament states that "the meetings of the Committees are public".  http://knesset.gov.il/rules/eng/ChapterH5.pdf  Paragraph 120 of the rules and procedure of the parliament states that – The all the protocols of the meetings of the Committees will be open to the public and will be published in the Knesset website according to this paragraph.

Verbatim committee transcripts are made upon the proposal of the chair or one-third of the committee members. As a rule, verbatim transcripts are made for all control hearings that committee have held.

As a rule, access to information is free of charge. However, in line with Article 33 of the Law on free access to information, the applicant of the request bears the costs related to photocopying, scanning and delivery of the requested information.
2: Costs of public authority related to the procedure for access to information, mainly for photocopying, are defined by the Regulation on costs in the procedure for access to information, and range from 0.10 euro per page (for A4 format) to 2.00 euro per page (for A3 format in color).

2: Rules on public access to proceedings in the Croatian parliament and its working bodies:  http://www.sabor.hr/Default.aspx?sec=734 these are key areas regulated by the Rules: - the presence of representatives of civic associations, non-governmental organizations and citizens as observer at the parliament session and sessions of working bodies,  - visits of organized groups of citizens to Parliament,  - way of recording sessions of Parliament and its bodies,  - direct radio and television broadcasts during the session,  -  way of registering domestic and foreign journalists in the Parliament  - website of the Parliament.
http://www.sabor.hr/Default.aspx?art=12571&re=13642&sec=1063 Content from these pages can be used without a prior consent by the author under the condition that the source of information is quoted.

2: According to the FOIA Act charges for access to information and re-use of information are only those ones that represent real material expenditures of the public bodies made when providing access to information or re-use of information. these charges are regulated by the Criteria proscribed by the Information Commissioner.

2: Reglamento del Senado, Título XVIII: Comisión de Ética y Transparencia del Senado. Reglamento para la tramitación de solicitudes de información de la Ley de Transparencia.

La información parlamentaria  está disponible para la ciudadanía a través del sitio web y puede ser usada y redistribuida, existe inclusive un sitio de datos abiertos con información de interés requerida especialmente por las organizaciones de monitoreo parlamentario. Artículo sexto de la Ley 20.285, de Transparencia, en relación con el 7°  del mismo texto legal.

This is a very complex area!  Oral and written evidence to Committees is published on the Committee's pages: e.g. http://www.parliament.uk/business/committees/committees-a-z/commons-select/home-affairs-committee/publications.  Command Papers are the collective name given to different types of papers prepared by the Government and presented to Parliament with the words "presented to Parliament by command of His/Her Majesty". The following documents are all types of Command Paper: Treaties, some White papers, some Green Papers, some Government replies to Select Committee reports, reports of Royal Commissions, reports of some major committees of inquiry, annual reports and statistics of certain bodies (judicial, penal, immigration).  These are published by Government rather than Parliament: https://www.gov.uk/government/publications and use "official document status" filter on LH side of page.  Also available for public inspection in Parliament.  For further info see http://www.parliament.uk/about/how/publications/government/
Assessed and paid by an independent body, IPSA
Yes, but only for mailing photocopies of Parliamentary material
